problem: David and Sarah have 30 marbles together. David has twice as many marbles as Sarah. How many marbles does David have more than Sarah?
solution:
Let the number of marbles David has be $d$ and the number Sarah has be $s$. The equations can be set as follows: \begin{align*}
d + s &= 30 \\
d &= 2s \\
\end{align*}Substituting for $d$ into the first equation gives $2s + s = 30$. Solving for $s$ gives $s = 10$. Thus $d = 20$. Therefore, David has $20 - 10 = \boxed{10}$ more marbles than Sarah.
